div.l: Oute of þe dore he gooth full pⁱriuely
Whan that he sawh his tyme softely
He loketh up and doun̄ tyll that he found
The clerkꝭes horse þ̉er as hit stode bound
Byhynde þe mylle vnder a leveshull
And to þe horse he gooth hym fayr͗e ⁊and well
He strypeth of þe brydel right anon̄e
And whan̄ the horse was lowse he gan̄ to gon̄
Toward þe Fenne þ̉er wylde marys renne
And forth with wehe thorou thikke ⁊and thynne
This myller goth ageyn̄ no word he seyd
But doth his note and with þe clerkꝭes pleyd
Tyll that hur corne was y grounde
And when̄ the mele ys sakked ⁊and y bound
This Iohn goth oute and fynde his horse awey
And gan̄ to crye harrow and weyleawey
Oure horse ys loste aleyn̄ for kokkꝭes bonys
Steppe on thi feete com̄ oute all at ones
Allas our͗e wardeyn̄ hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn̄ al forgate mele ⁊and corne
Alle was oute of his mynde his husbondry
What wey ys he gon̄ he gan̄ to crye
The wyfe com̄e lepynge inward at a renne
She seid allas youre horse gooth to þe Fenne
Wyth wylde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthanke com̄e on his hand that bonde hym so
And he þat bett̉er schuld haue knytte the Reyne
Allas quoth Iohn allas quoth Aleyn̄
Ley doun̄ thi swerd and y woll myn̄ also
Y am swyfte god wote as any Roo
By god he schall not askape us both
Why ne had þᵘou putte the capull in the lath
Ilhayle Aleyn̄ by god þᵘou arte a Fonne
These sely clerkꝭes haue ful fast y ronne
